qas.question: The immune systems of bacteria have enzymes that protect against infection by what kind of cells?
What are antimicrobial peptides that evolved as immune defense in eukaryotes called?
The idea of acquired immunity in jawed vertebrates is the basis of what medical treatment?
What is the ability to recognize and adapt to new specific pathogens called?
What is known for adapting and evolving slowly?
What do simple unicellular organisms lack?
What is an example of a less sophisticated defense mechanism that jawed vertebrates have?
What creates immunological memory before the initial responds to a pathogen?
What medical treatment is completely different from acquired immunity?

context: <b4_0>Pathogens<b4_0/> can rapidly evolve and adapt, and thereby avoid detection and neutralization by the immune system; however, multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary <b5_0>immune system<b5_0/>, in the form of enzymes that protect against <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>bacteriophage<a0_1/><a0_0/> infections<a0_2/>. Other basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes and remain in their modern descendants, such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis, antimicrobial peptides called <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>defensins<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, and the complement system. Jawed vertebrates, including humans, have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms, including the <b6_0>ability to adapt over time<b6_0/> to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>Adaptive (or acquired) immunity<b7_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen, leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity is the basis of <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b8_0>vaccination<b8_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>.
